p.text: In this Division:
includes the following:
a person or body who engages a lawyer to provide legal services or who employs a lawyer (including under a contract of service),
an employee or agent of a client,
an employer of a lawyer if the employer is:
the Commonwealth or a State or Territory, or
a body established by a law of the Commonwealth or a State or Territory,

if, under a law of a State or Territory relating to persons of unsound mind, a manager, committee or person (however described) is for the time being acting in respect of the person, estate or property of a client — a manager, committee or person so acting,
if a client has died — a personal representative of the client,
a successor to the rights and obligations of a client, being rights and obligations in respect of which a confidential communication was made.
[def am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[54], effective 1 January 2009]
means a communication made in such circumstances that, when it was made:
the person who made it, or
the person to whom it was made,
was under an express or implied obligation not to disclose its contents, whether or not the obligation arises under law.
means a document prepared in such circumstances that, when it was prepared:
the person who prepared it, or
the person for whom it was prepared,
was under an express or implied obligation not to disclose its contents, whether or not the obligation arises under law.
means:
an Australian lawyer, and
an Australian-registered foreign lawyer, and
an overseas-registered foreign lawyer or a natural person who, under the law of a foreign country, is permitted to engage in legal practice in that country, and
an employee or agent of a lawyer referred to in paragraph (a) , (b) or (c) .
[def subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[55], effective 1 January 2009]
includes the following:
an employee or agent of a party,

if, under a law of a State or Territory relating to persons of unsound mind, a manager, committee or person (however described) is for the time being acting in respect of the person, estate or property of a party — a manager, committee or person so acting,
if a party has died — a personal representative of the party,
a successor to the rights and obligations of a party, being rights and obligations in respect of which a confidential communication was made.
A reference in this Division to the commission of an act includes a reference to a failure to act.
Legislation cited in [51,065.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 r 3(1)(a).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.9.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Pt 3.10.

Part 75 r 3(1)(a) of the Supreme Court Rules applies UCPR r 1.9 to criminal proceedings conducted in the Supreme Court. Consequently, the client legal privilege provisions contained in Pt 3.10 — rather than common law principles — apply to issues of privilege that arise in those proceedings: R (Cth) v Petroulias (No 22) (2007) 213 FLR 293; [2007] NSWSC 692; BC200711116 .

The definition of client includes an employer, both in the ordinary sense of that word, and in the sense of a person who retains a lawyer under a contract to provide legal services. The definition also includes the agent of a client and an agent can include an independent consultant: Transgrid v Members of Lloyds Syndicate 3210 [2011] NSWSC 301 at [11]; BC201102533 , citing Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [124]. The definition may include lawyers who employ other lawyers. Relationships of that kind may occur as a result of specialisation within independent law firms.
Legislation cited in [51,065.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Pt 3.10.

The Dictionary definition of this expression picks up the meaning provided for in the Legal Profession Act 2004. The combined effect of these provisions is to clarify that admission to the legal profession, rather than status as the holder of a practising certificate, is the requisite qualification for the purposes of the privilege provisions in Evidence Act Pt 3.10 . This provides a legislative clarification of the issues discussed in Commonwealth v Vance (2005) 158 ACTR 47; [2005[ ACTCA 35; BC200506118 . The definition of “lawyer” also has the effect of extending client legal privilege to advice sought from an overseas lawyer — as outlined in Kennedy v Wallace (2004) 142 FCR 185 at 220; 213 ALR 108; [2004] FCAFC 337; BC200409050 (“the treatment of privilege as a jurisdictionally specific right is impractical and contrary to the underlying purpose in a modern society”).
Evidence is not to be adduced if, on objection by a client, the court finds that adducing the evidence would result in disclosure of:
a confidential communication made between the client and a lawyer, or
a confidential communication made between 2 or more lawyers acting for the client, or
the contents of a confidential document (whether delivered or not) prepared by the client, lawyer or another person,
for the dominant purpose of the lawyer, or one or more of the lawyers, providing legal advice to the client.
[s 118 am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[56], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 877–878, 879
ALRC 38 para 195(a)
Legislation cited in [51,070.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 117.
The Dictionary contains a definition of “document”. The terms “confidential communication” and “confidential document” are defined in s 117 of the Act.
Legislation cited in [51,070.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 118.

For the purposes of s 118 , the concept of legal advice is wide. It includes advice as to what should prudently and sensibly be done in the relevant legal context. It is not confined to specific advice about the content or effect of legislation or legal principles: AWB Ltd v Cole (2006) 155 FCR 30 at [44]; 234 ALR 651; [2006] FCA 1234; BC200607325 ; see also General Manager WorkCover Authority of NSW v Law Society of NSW (2006) 65 NSWLR 502; [2006] NSWCA 84; BC200602686 at [77]–[78] per McColl JA. However, documents which evidence transactions, as opposed to documents which are of themselves the giving or receiving of advice, do not attract the privilege: see In the matter of Idyllic Solutions Pty Ltd; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Hobbs [2012] NSWSC 581; BC201203724 at [58]ff and the authorities cited therein.

Although it does not use the word “privilege”, the section confers a privileged status on confidential client communications and documents prepared for the dominant purpose of providing or obtaining legal advice. The section thus continues the privileged status that communications of this type enjoyed at common law: Trade Practices Commission v Sterling (1979) 36 FLR 244 . The section adopts a “dominant purpose” test consistent with Esso Australia Resources Ltd v FCT (1999) 201 CLR 49; 168 ALR 123 at 137; [1999] HCA 67; BC9908417 ; and English and other common law authority: Waugh v British Railways Board [1980] AC 521 ; Guinness Peat Properties Ltd v Fitzroy Robinson Partnership [1987] 1 WLR 1027 as opposed to the sole purpose test laid down in Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 . Accordingly the privilege applies if the provision of legal advice was the “dominant”, rather than the “sole” purpose of the communication or the creation of the document. The word “purpose” as it used in the section refers to the purpose that led to the creation of the document or the making of the communication: Carnell v Mann (1998) 89 FCR 247; 159 ALR 647; BC9806603 . Accordingly, confidential records or interviews with a company’s employees conducted by that company’s lawyer would not fall within para (c) of s 118 but may attract privilege under s 119: Newcastle Wallsend Coal Co Pty Ltd v Court of Coal Mines Regulation (1997) 42 NSWLR 351; BC9704259 .

The dominant purpose of a communication is determined objectively having regard to the nature of the document, the circumstances in which it was commissioned or prepared and, if it is appropriate to inspect them, the contents of the document: Commissioner of Taxation (Cth) v Pratt Holdings Pty Ltd (2006) 225 ALR 266 at [30(3)] per Kenny J; Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (in liq) (2006) 59 ACSR 87; 203 FLR 1; [2006] NSWSC 899; BC200606961 at [37] . If the document would have been brought into existence irrespective of any intention to obtain professional legal services, then it is doubtful that the purpose of obtaining professional legal services could be regarded as the dominant purpose for the making of the document: Sparnon v Apand Pty Ltd (1996) 68 FCR 322; 138 ALR 735; BC9604157 ; Westpac Banking Corporation v 789TEN Pty Ltd (2005) 55 ACSR 519; [2005] NSWCA 321; BC200507412 . If the document was created for multiple purposes, and they were each of equal weight, neither could be characterised as dominant.

level.toc-caption: [51,070.20] Confidential documents made by the client, lawyer or other person

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,070.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 117.

heading.title: Confidential documents made by the client, lawyer or other person

p.text: Legal advice privilege applies if the communications or documents satisfy the dual requirements of confidentiality and preparation for the dominant purpose of lawyers providing legal advice to the client: Apple Computer Australia Pty Ltd v Wily [2002] NSWSC 855; BC200205438 . The contents of those kinds of documents attract the privilege irrespective of whether they have been prepared by the client, by the lawyer or by another person: Pratt Holdings Pty Ltd v Cmr of Taxation (2004) 136 FCR 357; 207 ALR 217; [2004] FCAFC 122; BC200402621 at [46]–[47] ; and cf Nickmar Pty Ltd v Preservatrice Skandia Insurance Ltd (1985) 3 NSWLR 44 (document prepared by opposing party).

The term “lawyer" means a person who is an "admitted legal practitioner" while acting in the professional capacity of a lawyer: General Manager WorkCover Authority of NSW v Law Society of NSW (2006) 65 NSWLR 502; [2006] NSWCA 84; BC200602686 at [90] per McColl JA. See also [21.5.27] . It does not include an industrial officer of a trade union: Wood v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1996) 67 IR 46 .

In determining whether or not a document was brought into existence for a purpose which was both privileged and dominant, the status of the legal practitioner may be relevant. An “in house” solicitor is, by reason of their position, more likely to act for purposes unrelated to legal proceedings than an external solicitor who, in the normal course, has no relevant function other than that involving legal proceedings and/or legal advice: Sydney Airports Corporation Limited v Singapore Airlines Limited [2005] NSWCA 47; BC200501073 at [24] cited in Banksia Mortgages Limited v Croker [2010] NSWSC 535; BC201003494 . See also Seven Network Limited v News Ltd [2005] FCA 142; BC200500600 ; Three Rivers District Council v Governor and Company of the Bank of England [2004] UKHL 48; [2005] 4 All ER 948; [2004] 3 WLR 1274 ; Telstra Corporation Limited v Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (No 2) [2007] FCA 1445; BC200707832 .

The term “client” includes an “employee or agent of a client”: s 117 . The question whether a communication between a lawyer and a third person involves that person acting as an agent of a client depends on the substance and purpose of the communication. A third person may be acting relevantly as an agent for the purpose of securing legal advice for the client, even where their role involves more than acting as a mere conduit for communications with the lawyer: DSE (Holdings) Pty Ltd v Interan Inc (2003) 135 FCR 151; 203 ALR 348; [2003] FCA 1191; BC200306380 at [94]–[96] ; Westpac Banking Corporation v 789Ten Pty Ltd (2005) 55 ACSR 519; [2005] NSWCA 321; BC200507412 ; but cf Pratt Holdings Pty Ltd v Cmr of Taxation (2004) 136 FCR 357; 207 ALR 217; [2004] FCAFC 122; BC200402621 at [46]–[47] .
Legislation cited in [51,070.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 118, 119.

The privilege only applies where the contents of the document or communication are confidential. This accords with the common law position under which there was no prohibition on the disclosure of matters such as the name of the client or matters observed by the lawyer: see generally [21.5.20] . Conversely, a document recording instructions to commence proceedings is likely to be confidential and privileged: Franks v Warringah Council [2010] NSWSC 1318; BC201008606 at [36]. The section prevents not only the disclosure of the document that constitutes the confidential communication but also any other evidence that would reveal its contents. This is consistent with the common law privilege, which extends to any document prepared by a lawyer or client from which the nature of the advice might be inferred: see Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (in liq) (2006) 59 ACSR 87; 203 FLR 1; [2006] NSWSC 899; BC200606961 at [14(e)] ; see also Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police v Propend Finance Pty Ltd (1997) 188 CLR 501 at 569; 141 ALR 545 per Gummow J.

A document that records a confidential communication may attract privilege even though the document itself is not a “communication”: Sugden v Sugden (2007) 70 NSWLR 301; 49 MVR 96; [2007] NSWCA 312; BC200709368 at [67]–[69] . Accordingly, even though the minutes of a meeting are not a communication, they may attract the provisions of ss 118 or 119 if they contain a record of confidential communications for the dominant purpose of either a lawyer providing legal advice, or a party being provided with professional legal services relating to proceedings, or anticipated or pending proceedings, in which it was, or might have been, a party: Franks v Warringah Council [2010] NSWSC 1318; BC201008606 .

Cases involving claims by clients against their former lawyers are to be treated differently to other actions where one of the parties may have received legal advice and access is sought by another party to that legal advice. The rationale behind that approach arises from the fact that in such a case, bearing in mind that court proceedings are public, the client brings that formerly confidential relationship into the public domain and in doing so, waives any right to claim the protection of legal professional privilege in relation to any communication between them, so far as necessary for the just determination of the claim: Paragon Finance Plc v Freshfields [1999] 1 WLR 1183 at 1188 ; Lillicrap v Nalder & Son [1993] 1 All ER 724; [1993] 1 WLR 94 , both cited with approval in Artistic Builders Pty Ltd v Nash [2009] NSWSC 102; BC200901284 at [56] ff .
Legislation cited in [51,070.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 8.

The Dictionary extends the definition of “document” to include any copy of the original: see Pt 2 cl 8 . This has the effect that, subject to questions of waiver, the privilege will still apply to copies of a privileged document that come into the hands of other parties: Carnell v Mann (1998) 89 FCR 247; 159 ALR 647; BC9806603 . In this respect the section also departs from the general common law position: see [21.5.60] . The section leaves open the question, which has troubled the common law, as to whether the privilege is capable of applying to copies where the original document is not privileged: this topic is discussed at [21.5.60] .

The section conditionally precludes the admissibility of the particular communications and documents into “evidence”. This inadmissibility applies not only to the final curial hearing of proceedings (as to which see Cockier v Dennis O’Connor Pty Ltd [2007] NSWDC 4 at [18], [19]) but also the hearing of interlocutory applications: KC v Shiley Inc (FCA, Tamberlin J, NG 633 of 1993, 11 July 1997, unreported, BC9703039); Trade Practices Commission v Port Adeaide Wool Co Pty Ltd (1995) 60 FCR 366; 132 ALR 645; BC9501540 ; Telstra Corp Ltd v Australis Media Holdings (1997) 41 NSWLR 277; BC9700290 . However, the section does not apply to interlocutory procedures such as discovery: Spalding v Radio Canberra Pty Ltd [2009] ACTSC 26; BC200901770 . Where the privilege question arises in relation to the out of court use of documents, in particular their use in connection with administrative inquiries and investigations, the common law position will continue to apply: Baker v Campbell (1983) 153 CLR 52; 49 ALR 385; BC8300114 .
Legislation cited in [51,070.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 132.

Where there is an apparent basis for the assertion of privilege, the court must satisfy itself that the client is aware of the possible privilege and has an opportunity to make the claim: Evidence Act 1995 s 132 .

The authorities emphasize the need for focussed and specific evidence in order to ground a claim for privilege. Verbal formulae and bare conclusory assertions of purpose are not sufficient. The court should be assisted by evidence of the thought processes behind, or the nature and purpose of advice being sought in respect of, each particular document. The fact that generalised evidence may not be the subject of challenge in cross examination does not mean that such evidence must be accepted, particularly if it is manifestly inadequate: Barnes v Cmr of Taxation (2007) 242 ALR 601; [2007] FCAFC 88; BC200707308 at [18] ; Carbotech-Australia Pty Ltd v Yates [2008] NSWSC 1151; BC200809838 ; Michael Wilson and Partners Ltd v Nicholls [2008] NSWSC 1230; BC200812458 at [28] . A sufficient evidentiary basis for the privilege may be provided by a legal adviser’s evidence about the circumstances surrounding the client’s communication and inferences from the document itself: Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (Receivers and Managers appointed) (in liq) (2006) 59 ACSR 87; [2006] NSWSC 899; BC200606961 at [28] (evidence given by an employed solicitor closely involved in the day-to-day carriage of the matter, in a position of responsibility); Re OPEL Networks Pty Ltd (in liq) [2010] NSWSC 142; BC201001033 (evidence given by experienced general counsel of a government department that confidential communications were legal advices).
Evidence is not to be adduced if, on objection by a client, the court finds that adducing the evidence would result in disclosure of:
a confidential communication between the client and another person, or between a lawyer acting for the client and another person, that was made, or
the contents of a confidential document (whether delivered or not) that was prepared,

for the dominant purpose of the client being provided with professional legal services relating to an Australian or overseas proceeding (including the proceeding before the court), or an anticipated or pending Australian or overseas proceeding, in which the client is or may be, or was or might have been, a party.
ALRC 38 para 195(b)

The notes in [50,070.5] , [50,070.10] , [50,070.20] – [50,070.40] also apply to the privilege referred to in this section. Subject to the substitution of “dominant” purpose for the “sole” purpose test, the section is generally consistent with the previous common law position: see generally [21.5.20] and [21.5.80] .
Legislation cited in [51,075.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 119.

Third party communications are potentially privileged under s 119 if they satisfy the dominant purpose test in relation to the conduct of litigation. In this respect the section is consistent with the common law position — that the litigation must either be on foot or reasonably apprehended as a “real prospect”: Wheeler v Le Marchant (1881) 17 Ch D 675 ; New South Wales v Jackson [2007] NSWCA 279; BC200708676 at [66]–[69] (school accident report — departmental policy requiring reports — reports asserted intended use in connection with litigation). The time at which the questions of purpose and anticipated proceedings are to be assessed may vary according to the facts of a particular case. However, when the document in question is a report commissioned by a solicitor, the date on which the report was commissioned is the relevant date: Singapore Airlines v Sydney Airports Corporation [2004] NSWSC 380; BC200402451 .

Matters relevant in assessing whether an obligation of confidence should be inferred in circumstances outside that of lawyer and client include the nature of the relationship in question, the nature of the communications or documents in question, and the purposes for, and context in, which they were made: see Rickard Constructions Pty Ltd v Rickard Hails Moretti Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 234; BC200602062 ; see also New South Wales v Jackson [2007] NSWCA 279; BC200708676 ; New Cap Reinsurance Corp Ltd (in liq) v Christensen [2008] NSWSC 93; BC200800621 ; see further [21.5.35] and [21.5.37] .
Evidence is not to be adduced if, on objection by a party who is not represented in the proceeding by a lawyer, the court finds that adducing the evidence would result in disclosure of:
a confidential communication between the party and another person, or
the contents of a confidential document (whether delivered or not) that was prepared, either by or at the direction or request of, the party,
for the dominant purpose of preparing for or conducting the proceeding.
[subs (2) rep Act 55 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1]
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 877, 883
ALRC 38 para 195(b)
Legislation cited in [51,080.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 119, s 120.

The provisions of s 120 confer a litigation privilege upon unrepresented litigants in relation to confidential communications and documents where the dominant purpose is the preparation for, or the conduct of, the proceedings. A significant difference between the present section and the litigation privilege conferred by s 119 , is that the present section is confined to the proceedings in question and does not extend to communications and documents made in connection with anticipated proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,085] s 121 Loss of client legal privilege: generally

leg:heading.title: Loss of client legal privilege: generally

p.text: This Division does not prevent the adducing of evidence relevant to a question concerning the intentions, or competence in law, of a client or party who has died.

This Division does not prevent the adducing of evidence if, were the evidence not adduced, the court would be prevented, or it could reasonably be expected that the court would be prevented, from enforcing an order of an Australian court.
This Division does not prevent the adducing of evidence of a communication or document that affects a right of a person.

level.toc-caption: [51,085.5] Affecting a right of a person

heading.title: Affecting a right of a person

p.text: The provisions of s 121(3) apply only in relation to communications directly affecting a person’s rights: R v P (2001) 53 NSWLR 664; [2001] NSWCA 473; BC200107804 .
Legislation cited in [51,085.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Section 121.

Section 121 does not abrogate a claim for privilege that an executor or putative executor has in his or her own right where privileged documents or communications are relevant to the intentions or competence of the deceased. That is because the deceased was not, in such circumstances, the client or the party entitled to the privilege. The rational construction of s 121 is that it abrogates a claim for privilege which the deceased person, as a client or party, could have maintained but for his or her death, if the privileged documents or communications are relevant to the deceased’s intentions or competence: d’Apice v Gutkovich — Estate of Abraham (No 1) [2010] NSWSC 1336; BC201008737 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,090] s 122 Loss of client legal privilege: consent and related matters

leg:heading.title: Loss of client legal privilege: consent and related matters

p.text: This Division does not prevent the adducing of evidence given with the consent of the client or party concerned.

Subject to subsection (5) , this Division does not prevent the adducing of evidence if the client or party concerned has acted in a way that is inconsistent with the client or party objecting to the adducing of the evidence because it would result in a disclosure of a kind referred to in section 118 , 119 or 120 .
Without limiting subsection (2) , a client or party is taken to have so acted if:
the client or party knowingly and voluntarily disclosed the substance of the evidence to another person, or
the substance of the evidence has been disclosed with the express or implied consent of the client or party.

The reference in subsection (3)(a) to a knowing and voluntary disclosure does not include a reference to a disclosure by a person who was, at the time of the disclosure, an employee or agent of the client or party, or of a lawyer of the client or party, unless the employee or agent was authorised by the client, party or lawyer to make the disclosure.
A client or party is not taken to have acted in a manner inconsistent with the client or party objecting to the adducing of the evidence merely because:
the substance of the evidence has been disclosed:
in the course of making a confidential communication or preparing a confidential document, or
as a result of duress or deception, or
under compulsion of law, or

if the client or party is a body established by, or a person holding an office under, an Australian law — to the Minister, or the Minister of the Commonwealth, the State or Territory, administering the law, or part of the law, under which the body is established or the office is held, or

of a disclosure by a client to another person if the disclosure concerns a matter in relation to which the same lawyer is providing, or is to provide, professional legal services to both the client and the other person, or

of a disclosure to a person with whom the client or party had, at the time of the disclosure, a common interest relating to the proceeding or an anticipated or pending proceeding in an Australian court or a foreign court.

This Division does not prevent the adducing of evidence of a document that a witness has used to try to revive the witness’s memory about a fact or opinion or has used as mentioned in section 32 (Attempts to revive memory in court) or 33 (Evidence given by police officers).
[s 122 subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[57], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 885
ALRC 38 para 195
Legislation cited in [51,090.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 122(2), s 122(5).

Waiver of privilege is the term conventionally applied to describe the circumstances in which a party may adduce evidence that would otherwise attract client legal privilege. The terms of s 122(2) were intended to implement the guidance provided by the High Court in Mann v Carnell (1999) 201 CLR 1; 168 ALR 86; [1999] HCA 66; BC9908416 , where it was observed (at [29]) that it is the inconsistency between the conduct of the client and the maintenance of confidentiality which brings about a waiver. Accordingly, the essential consideration identified in s 122(2) is whether the conduct of the person concerned is "inconsistent" in that sense, and reflects the common law approach to implied waiver: Chen v City Convenience Leasing Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 297; BC200506955 ; Ashfield Municipal Council v Roads and Traffic Authority of NSW [2004] NSWSC 917; BC200406542 at [14] ; French v Polar Technologies International Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1260; BC200609651 at [13] ; New Cap Reinsurance Corp Ltd (in liq) v Renaissance Reinsurance Ltd [2007] NSWSC 258; BC200701984 at [44] .

The party seeking to adduce the contentious evidence bears the onus of establishing waiver: Nine Films and Television Pty Ltd v Ninox Television Ltd (2005) 65 IPR 442; [2005] FCA 356; BC200501812 at [21] ; Rich v Harrington (2007) 245 ALR 106; [2007] FCA 1987; BC200710886 at [8] .

Waiver by disclosure: As s 122(3) provides, knowing and voluntary disclosure of the substance of privileged information will result in loss of the privilege. Similarly, disclosure of the confidential information with the actual or implied consent of the client results in loss of the privilege: Attorney-General (NT) v Maurice (1986) 161 CLR 475; 69 ALR 31; BC8601398 ; Trade Practices Commission v TNT Management Pty Ltd (1984) 56 ALR 647 at 698–700 per Franki J; Conlon v Conlons Ltd [1952] 2 All ER 462 ; Chen v City Convenience Leasing Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 297; BC200506955 and see generally [21.5.110] .

Whether disclosure amounts to a disclosure of the substance of a privileged communication, and thus a waiver, will necessarily involve a question of degree. In determining what constitutes disclosure, a distinction is to be drawn between a mere reference to the fact of advice having been obtained and a disclosure of the content or the substance of the advice: see Mann v Carnell (1990) 201 CLR 1; 168 ALR 86; [1999] HCA 66; BC9908416 ; Chen v City Convenience Leasing , above; AWB Ltd v Cole (No 5) (2006) 155 FCR 30; [2006] FCA 1234; BC200607325 (conscious and voluntary decision to use the substance of legal advice in dealings for commercial reasons — partial waiver). See also Bennett v Australian Customs Service (2004) 140 FCR 101; 210 ALR 220; [2004] FCAFC 237; BC200405409 (advice that a particular regulation did not prohibit public comment — waiver). Inadvertent or unauthorised disclosure does not result in the loss of the privilege: Hooker Corp Ltd v Darling Harbour Authority (1987) 9 NSWLR 538 ; AWB Ltd v Cole (No 1) (2006) 152 FCR 382; 232 ALR 743; [2006] FCA 571; BC200603312 esp at [136] (no waiver of privilege by inadvertent production of document). Conversely, if the conclusions of legal advice, and the reasoning underlying those conclusions, are disclosed, that is likely to amount to a disclosure of the substance of the advice: Fenwick v Wambo Coal Pty Ltd (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 353; BC201104019 .

In forming a view about whether there has been a mere reference to the substance of legal advice, as distinct from disclosure, some cases may require an impressionistic and finely balanced assessment. In such cases, a court should not readily conclude that the privilege has been waived: Landmark Underwriting Agency Pty Ltd v Kilborn [2006] NSWSC 1108; BC200608470 (“borderline case” — no waiver); Limit (No 3) Ltd v ACE Insurance Ltd (No 3) [2009] NSWSC 1061; BC200909124 (no waiver — documents did not “reasonably necessary” to understand a draft report from an expert). See also the notes at [21.5.110] and [21.5.115] regarding waiver of privilege.

Waiver by implication: Apart from cases of actual disclosure, waiver may be implied by the nature of the issues in dispute. A typical example of such a situation is provided by cases involving claims by clients against their former lawyers. In these cases the client brings that formerly confidential relationship into the public domain and in doing so, waives any right to claim the protection of legal professional privilege in relation to any communication whose disclosure is necessary for the just determination of the claim: Paragon Finance Plc v Freshfields [1999] 1 WLR 1183 at 1188; [1999] All ER (D) 251 ; Lillicrap v Nalder & Son [1993] 1 All ER 724; [1993] 1 WLR 94 , both cited with approval in Artistic Builders Pty Ltd v Nash [2009] NSWSC 102; BC200901284 at [56] : see [21.5.115] .

Compulsory disclosure: Section 122(5) makes it clear that there is no voluntary waiver of privilege where the disclosure was made in compliance with an enforceable legal obligation: Akins v Abigroup (1998) 43 NSWLR 539; BC9802114 (witness statements served in compliance with court’s orders — compulsion made out — no inconsistency/waiver); Ingot Capital Investments Pty Ltd v Macquarie Equity [2008] NSWSC 25; BC200800207 (evidence provided in obedience to court’s directions —– compulsion made out); Waugh Asset Management v Merrill Lynch [2010] NSWSC 197; BC201001442 (access sought to underlying documents that “inform a state of mind” arising from paragraphs of a statement produced under compulsion — no inconsistency/waiver).

Compulsory disclosure and mistake: In the context of formal discovery, in the absence of an obvious mistake once inspection has been allowed any privilege attaching to that document is to be regarded as waived: Biseja Pty Ltd v NSI Group Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1497; BC200611432 ; Grace v Grace [2010] NSWSC 1514; BC201010438 ; Adelaide Bank Ltd v Abdelkodous [2011] NSWSC 32; BC201101031 . It is important to bear in mind that in such a situation, the question is not whether the disputed documents were obviously privileged, but whether their disclosure was an obvious mistake. These are quite distinct concepts, because a party may voluntarily disclose a privileged document for a myriad of reasons: Grace v Grace, above. What may constitute an “obvious mistake” for these purposes will depend upon the circumstances of the case: see for example Meltend Pty Ltd v Restoration Clinics of Australia Pty Ltd (1997) 75 FCR 511; 145 ALR 391; BC9702667 ; Guinness Peat Properties Ltd v Fitzroy Robinson Partnership (a firm) [1987] 2 All ER 716; [1987] 1 WLR 107 ; Derby and Co Pty Ltd v Weldon (No 8) [1990] 3 All ER 762; [1991] 1 WLR 73 .

In Meltend Pty Ltd v Restoration Clinics of Australia Pty Ltd (1997) 75 FCR 511; 145 ALR 391; BC9702667 Goldberg J said that in the context of disputes about mistaken disclosure in the course of procedural discovery, the issue of waiver “should be determined by reference to the express or imputed intention of the disclosing party”: Meltend Pty Ltd v Restoration Clinics of Australia Pty Ltd (1997) 75 FCR 511; 145 ALR 391; BC9702667 (solicitor had reviewed and settled the list and had turned his mind to the particular document and decided that the document was not privileged — waiver of privilege); compare Armstrong Strategic Management and Marketing Pty Ltd v Expense Reduction Analysts Group Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 393; BC201202767 at [56] (multiple copies of privileged documents — multiple reviewers involved in discovery process — inconsistent privilege claims and disclosure of duplicates — basis for inference of mistaken disclosure — no waiver).

level.toc-caption: [51,090.15] Refreshing recollection and loss of privilege

heading.title: Refreshing recollection and loss of privilege

p.text: The use of a privileged document to refresh recollection will result in loss of any privilege that would otherwise apply: MGICA (1992) Ltd v Kenny & Good Pty Ltd (No 2) (1996) 61 FCR 236; 135 ALR 743 at 749 (expert refreshing recollection from draft report): Grundy v Lewis (FCA, Cooper J, 1212/98, 21 September 1998, unreported, BC9805020); Newcastle Wallsend Coal Co Pty Ltd v Court of Coal Mines Regulation (1997) 42 NSWLR 351 at 389; BC9704259 ; Spalding v Radio Canberra Pty Ltd (2009) 166 ACTR 14; [2009] ACTSC 26; BC200901770 at [31]–[61] (plaintiff’s proof of evidence). But no waiver occurs unless a particular document has been used to refresh recollection. A witness who reviews a file prior to giving evidence does not thereby waive privilege over the entire contents of the file: Watson v McLernon [2000] NSWSC 114; BC200000156 .

level.toc-caption: [51,090.20] Loss of privilege — material tendered on ex parte applications

heading.title: Loss of privilege — material tendered on ex parte applications

p.text: It has been held that a trustee seeking judicial advice pursuant to s 63 of the Trustee Act does not lose the privilege attaching to a legal opinion by placing it before the court in association with such application. This is because the court is not “another person” as contemplated by s 122 and because the placing of such an opinion before a court, on a confidential basis and on an ex parte application, is not an action inconsistent with a continuing intention to maintain confidentiality: Macedonian Orthodox Community Church St Petka Inc v His Eminence Petar (2006) 66 NSWLR 112; [2006] NSWCA 160; BC200604835 at [45] ff per Beazley JA.

The operation of such a principle will apply, prima facie, to an instance where privileged material is placed before a court on an ex parte hearing of an application for extension of time for service. The nature of such an application, along with the fact that no person(s) other than the applicants for the extension order would have a right or an expectation of participation in such a hearing and accordingly, the privilege attaching to the material in question would not, without more, be lost merely because it was placed before the court for the purposes of an application of that kind. If however, the material is placed before the court by a party in those circumstances, and that party knows that the other party has a right to seek to have any extension order discharged, the situation would seemingly be different. In those circumstances, having used the privileged material in support of an order which that party knew would be susceptible to an application for discharge by the other party, there would be no entitlement to the maintenance of confidentiality. Any attempt to do so in such circumstances would be inconsistent with the use to which the party deliberately chose to make of the material in the context of an extension application: Weston v Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1288; BC201008290 esp at [15]–[17] and [43]–[46] citing Onefone Australia Pty Ltd v One Tel Ltd; Weston v Publishing Broadcasting Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1320; BC200709976 and Mann v Carnell (1999) 201 CLR 1; 168 ALR 86; [1999] HCA 66; BC9908416 (but see the subsequent decision in Weston v Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1288; BC201008290 at [17] (concluding that privilege had not been lost)).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,095] s 123 Loss of client legal privilege: defendants

leg:heading.title: Loss of client legal privilege: defendants

p.text: In a criminal proceeding, this Division does not prevent a defendant from adducing evidence unless it is evidence of:
a confidential communication made between an associated defendant and a lawyer acting for that person in connection with the prosecution of that person, or
the contents of a confidential document prepared by an associated defendant or by a lawyer acting for that person in connection with the prosecution of that person.
“Associated defendant” is defined in the Dictionary.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,100] s 124 Loss of client legal privilege: joint clients

leg:heading.title: Loss of client legal privilege: joint clients

p.text: This section only applies to a civil proceeding in connection with which 2 or more parties have, before the commencement of the proceeding, jointly retained a lawyer in relation to the same matter.
This Division does not prevent one of those parties from adducing evidence of:
a communication made by any one of them to the lawyer, or
the contents of a confidential document prepared by or at the direction or request of any one of them,
in connection with that matter.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,105] s 125 Loss of client legal privilege: misconduct

leg:heading.title: Loss of client legal privilege: misconduct

p.text: This Division does not prevent the adducing of evidence of:

a communication made or the contents of a document prepared by a client or lawyer (or both), or a party who is not represented in the proceeding by a lawyer, in furtherance of the commission of a fraud or an offence or the commission of an act that renders a person liable to a civil penalty, or

a communication or the contents of a document that the client or lawyer (or both), or the party, knew or ought reasonably to have known was made or prepared in furtherance of a deliberate abuse of a power.
For the purposes of this section, if the commission of the fraud, offence or act, or the abuse of power, is a fact in issue and there are reasonable grounds for finding that:
the fraud, offence or act, or the abuse of power, was committed, and
a communication was made or document prepared in furtherance of the commission of the fraud, offence or act or the abuse of power,
the court may find that the communication was so made or the document so prepared.
In this section:
means a power conferred by or under an Australian law.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 885
ALRC 38 paras 195, 197–198

The circumstances in which “misconduct” will preclude reliance on client legal privilege are generally consistent with the position at common law: see generally the discussion at [21.5.40] where the matter is discussed and R v Cox and Railton (1884) 14 QBD 153 ; O’Rourke v Darbishire [1920] AC 581; see also Carbotech-Australia Pty Ltd v Yates [2008] NSWSC 1151; BC200809838 at [21] and the authorities cited therein.

In order to displace a claim of client legal privilege on the grounds of misconduct, there must be a clear statement of the relevant misconduct and sufficient probative evidence of its apparent occurrence: Commissioner of Australian Federal Police v Propend Finance Pty Ltd (1997) 188 CLR 501 esp at 566; 141 ALR 545 per McHugh J; Zemanek v Commonwealth Bank of Australia [1997] FCA 1016; BC9704991 at [5] per Hill J; Kang v Kwan [2001] NSWSC 698; BC200104799 at [36]–[37] per Santow J; Lewis v Nortex (in liq) [2002] NSWSC 1245; BC200208330 at [8] ; Nuclear Utility Technology and Environmental Corporation Inc v Australian Broadcasting Corp [2009] NSWSC 78; BC200900997 .

For the purpose of the section the concepts of "fraud" and “deliberate abuse of power” require some element of dishonesty: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2001] NSWSC 222; BC200101315 ; Kang v Kwan [2001] NSWSC 698; BC200104799 esp at [37]ff ; ATH Transport SA v JAS (International) Australia Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 956; BC200206071 ; Van Der Lee v New South Wales [2002] NSWCA 286; BC200205002 . But the communication or the preparation of the document must have occurred “in furtherance” of the impugned purpose: (privilege is not inapplicable merely because the communication or document either records, or is otherwise relevant to, a fraud or crime). Moreover, for the section to be invoked, something more must be shown than simply that the documents or communications are relevant to, or might disclose, a fraud or abuse of power. The moving party must demonstrate, by admissible evidence, that the communications were made, or the documents prepared, in furtherance of the commission of the fraud or abuse of power: Franks v Warringah Council [2010] NSWSC 1318; BC201008606 at [39]–[41] ; Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police v Propend Finance Pty Ltd (1997) 188 CLR 501 at 556; 141 ALR 545 ; Attorney General for the Northern Territory v Kearney (1985) 158 CLR 500 at 516; 61 ALR 55; BC8501109 . Overall, the section requires an objective determination as to whether the relevant communication was in furtherance of the commission of the fraud or an offence. Except to the extent that the concept of a “deliberate abuse of power” suggests the contrary, the section is not directly concerned with the actual subjective intentions of the parties to the communication or the document — although often the client’s subjective purpose is ordinarily relevant and sometimes determinative of the character of the impugned evidence: Carbotech-Australia Pty Ltd v Yates [2008] NSWSC 1151; BC200809838 at [22]–[30] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,110] s 126 Loss of client legal privilege: related communications and documents

leg:heading.title: Loss of client legal privilege: related communications and documents

p.text: If, because of the application of section 121 , 122 , 123 , 124 or 125 , this Division does not prevent the adducing of evidence of a communication or the contents of a document, those sections do not prevent the adducing of evidence of another communication or document if it is reasonably necessary to enable a proper understanding of the communication or document.

A lawyer advises his client to understate her income for the previous year to evade taxation because of her potential tax liability “as set out in my previous letter to you dated 11 August 1994”. In proceedings against the taxpayer for tax evasion, evidence of the contents of the letter dated 11 August 1994 may be admissible (even if that letter would otherwise be privileged) to enable a proper understanding of the second letter.

If a privileged document is voluntarily disclosed for forensic purposes and a thorough apprehension or appreciation of the character, significance or implications of that document requires the disclosure of source documents which would otherwise be protected by client legal privilege, then ordinarily the test laid down by s 126 will be satisfied and the privilege will be held to have been lost: Towney v Minister for Land and Water Conservation (1997) 76 FCR 401; 147 ALR 402; BC9703184 ; Whitfield v Law Society of NSW (NSWSC, Dunford J, 30006/97, 16 July 1998, unreported, BC9803174); see also Ziade v Randwick City Council [2000] NSWSC 1198; BC200007778 .
